element.label: GeneralR1
element.definition: No description

element.label: ClinicalSynopsisItem
element.definition: Narrative summary or overview about a patient and their health situation, from the perspective of a healthcare provider

extension.valueString:
Use to record a narrative, summary view about the patient and their health situation. This unstructured summary may include identified health issues; health care provided; associated interpretation; patient understanding; and enable communication about some of the softer, more subjective aspects of the patient’s experience and journey. Most commonly this summary is likely to be related to a specific health event such as a specific consultation or hospital admission, but may also be used to summarise the patient's health experience over varying time periods.

In practice, a clinical synopsis is used to capture a summary that will complement the existing structured clinical record, by allowing clinicians to express subtle nuances, subjective information or interpretations about the patient's situation, clinical events or activities that might not be obvious through structured data alone. For example, a clinical synopsis can communicate a concise summary of the patient's hospital admission as one component of a comprehensive and structured Discharge Summary document.
Clinical synopsis, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-09-28]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.409

element.label: Synopsis

element.label: Problem/Diagnosis
element.definition: No description

element.label: ProblemDiagnosisItem
element.definition: Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

extension.valueString:
Use to record details about a single, identified health problem or diagnosis.

Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is often not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation using this item, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing information and reaching or exceeding diagnostic criteria supporting formalisation of the label of 'diagnosis'. It is not necessary to classify the condition as a 'problem' or 'diagnosis', especially as a problem may evolve into a formal diagnosis as evidence is gathered. The data requirements to support documentation of either are identical, with additional data structure required to support inclusion of the evidence if and when it becomes available. In practice, most problems or diagnoses do not sit at either end of the problem-diagnosis spectrum, but somewhere in between.

Not to be used to describe reasons for encounter - use the 'Reason for encounter' item.

Not to be used to describe procedures - use the 'Procedure' item.

Not to be used to describe adverse reactions - use the 'Adverse reaction' item.

Not to be used to describe symptoms, examination findings, diagnostic test results or health risk assessments.

Not to be used to describe differential diagnoses.

Problems: the individual's expressed desire to lose weight, but without a formal diagnosis of obesity; or an ongoing relationship conflict with a family member; or impaired glucose tolerance, where blood glucose levels are higher than normal but not high enough to be classified as diabetes.

Formal diagnoses: a cancer that is supported by historical information, examination findings, histopathological findings, radiological findings and meets all requirements for known diagnostic criteria; or diabetes mellitus per formal diagnostic criteria.

Problem/Diagnosis, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-09-28]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.169.

Condition, FHIR Resource, R4 [Internet]. Health Level Seven International; [cited: 2020-09-22]. Available from: https://www.hl7.org/fhir/condition-definitions.html.

element.label: ProblemDiagnosisName
element.definition: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

extension.valueString:
Coding with a terminology is strongly recommended.
Value set: ADHA value set which includes SNOMED CT-AU values that cover a broad range of clinical concepts to support the representation of conditions, including problems, diagnoses and disorders. It uses content from the Problem diagnosis reference set.

13645005 | COPD |

element.label: DateClinicallyRecognised
element.definition: Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.

extension.valueString: Partial dates are allowed. This data element is deliberately names as ‘clinically recognised’ rather than 'Date of diagnosis' to reflect the inclusion of problems as well as formal diagnoses.

element.label: ActiveInactiveStatus
element.definition: The activity or clinical impact of the problem or diagnosis on the individual.

extension.valueString:
The active/inactive status reflects the activity or clinical impact of a condition on the individual. For example a patient may have a known history of asthma, but had no symptoms for 5 years - a confirmed diagnosis that should remain in a problem list, but with an inactive status indicating no active treatment is required.

Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. 
Value set: HL7 AU base 'Status' value set needs to be constrained to two values only - 'active' and 'inactive'.

element.label: CourseDescription
element.definition: Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset.

element.label: Comment
element.definition: Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.

element.label: LastUpdated

If the positive presence of a 'Problem/Diagnosis item' has been added to the health record, this Exclusion item becomes redundant.

Record as a single instance in a health record; updated and revised over time as a new version each time it is asserted. 

An absence statement can only be considered correct and accurate at the time it was asserted.
Not to be used to record the absence of any available information about Problems and Diagnoses - use the 'Problem/Diagnosis absence item'.

element.label: AdverseReactions
element.definition: No description

element.label: AdverseReactionRiskItem
element.definition: Risk of harmful or undesirable physiological response which is unique to the individual and associated with exposure to a known substance.

extension.valueString:
Use to provide a single place within the health record to document a range of clinical statements about adverse reactions, including:
- record a clinical assessment of the individual’s propensity for a potential future reaction upon re-exposure; and
- record cumulative information about the reaction to each exposure.

Use to record information about the positive presence of the risk of an adverse reaction:
- to support direct clinical care of an individual;
- as part of a managed adverse reaction or allergy/intolerance list;
- to support exchange of information about the propensity and events related to adverse reactions;
- to inform adverse reaction reporting; and
- to assist computerised knowledge-based activities such as clinical decision support and alerts.

Use to record information about the risk of adverse reactions to a broad range of substances, including: incipients and excipients in medicinal preparations; biological products; metal salts; and organic chemical compounds.

Adverse reaction may be:
- an immune mediated reaction - Types I-IV (including allergic reactions and hypersensitivities); or
- a non-immune mediated reaction - including pseudo-allergic reactions, side effects, intolerances, drug toxicities (eg to Gentamicin).
In clinical practice distinguishing between immune-mediated and non-immune mediated reactions is difficult and often not practical. Identification of the type of reaction is not a proxy for seriousness or risk of harm to the patient, which is better expressed by the manifestation in clinical practice.

The risk of an adverse reaction event or manifestation should not be recorded without identifying a proposed causative substance or class of substance. If there is uncertainty that a specific substance is the cause, this uncertainty can be recorded using the ‘Verification status’ data element. If there are multiple possible substances that may have caused a reaction/manifestation, each substance should be recorded using a separate instance of this adverse reaction archetype with the ‘Status’ set to an initial state of ‘Unconfirmed’ so that adverse reaction checking can be activated in clinical systems. Once the substance, agent or class is later proven not to be the cause for a given reaction then the ‘Status’ can be modified to ‘Refuted’.

This item has been designed to allow recording of information about a specific substance (amoxycillin, oysters, or bee sting venom) or, alternatively, a class of substance (eg Penicillins). If a class of substance is recorded then identification of the exact substance can be recorded on a per exposure basis.

Adverse reaction risk, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-09-28]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.1713.

AllergyIntolerance, FHIR Resource, R4 [Internet]. Health Level Seven International; [cited: 2020-09-22]. Available from: https://www.hl7.org/fhir/R4/allergyintolerance.html.

element.label: SubstanceName
element.definition: Identification of a substance, or substance class, which is considered to put the individual at risk of an adverse reaction event.

extension.valueString:
Both an individual substance and a substance class are valid entries in 'Substance'. A substance may be a compound of simpler substances, for example a medicinal product.

Coding with a terminology is strongly recommended.
Value set: ADHA value set, contains all agents that may be responsible for causing adverse reactions. This set includes all AMT product concepts as well as SNOMED CT-AU substances such as chemical, material and dietary substances.

element.label: Criticality
element.definition: Estimate of the potential clinical harm, or seriousness, from a future exposure to the identified substance.

extension.valueString:
The default criticality value for any propensity to an adverse reaction should be 'Low Risk', indicating at the very least a relative contraindication to deliberate or voluntary exposure to the substance. 'High Risk' is flagged if the clinician has identified a propensity for a more serious or potentially life-threatening reaction, such as anaphylaxis, and implies an absolute contraindication to deliberate or voluntary exposure to the substance.

Coding with a terminology is strongly recommended.
Value set: ADHA value set, designated as AU Base, describing the potential for harm on subsequent exposure to a substance.
This data element should not be used to record the severity of the manifestation.

element.label: VerificationStatus
element.definition: Assertion about certainty associated about the potential risk of a reaction to the identified substance.

extension.valueString:
Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Value set: ADHA values set, designated as AU Base, providing concepts that indicate whether the adverse reaction assertion is verified.

element.label: ReactionEvent
element.definition: Details about each adverse reaction event linked to exposure to the identified 'Substance'.

extension.valueString: Use a separate instance of this group to record details about the reaction to each exposure.

element.label: Manifestation
element.definition: Clinical symptom and/or sign that were observed or associated with the adverse reaction.

extension.valueString:
Coding with a terminology is strongly recommended.
Value set: ADHA Clinical manifestation reference set, which contains SNOMED CT-AU concepts that can be used to describe manifestations.

element.label: Comment
element.definition: Additional narrative about the adverse reaction risk not captured in other fields.

element.label: LastUpdated
element.definition: The date this adverse reaction summary was last updated.

element.label: AdverseReactionRiskExclusionItemR1
element.short: Adverse reaction risk exclusion item R1
element.definition: A positive statement about no known adverse reactions, accurate only at the time of recording.

extension.valueString:
Use to assert a clear and unambiguous statement about exclusion of known adverse reactions in the health record. This approach is used in preference to the use of flags or terminology alone to express negation. It is intended for use within a Adverse reaction list or a health record extract.

If the positive presence of an 'Adverse reaction risk item' has been added to the health record, this Exclusion item becomes redundant.

Record as a single instance in a health record; updated and revised over time as a new version each time it is asserted. 

An absence statement can only be considered correct and accurate at the time it was asserted.
Not to be used to record the absence of any available information about Adverse reaction risks - use the 'Adverse reaction risk absence item'.
Exclusion - global, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-08-24]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.2733

element.label: AdverseReactionRiskExclusionStatement
element.definition: Positive statement that there are no known adverse reactions for inclusion.

extension.valueString:
If the exclusion statement is specific about types of reactions, such as reactions to food or medications, then each type will be represented in a separate instance of this data element.

Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Value set: to be set to 'Nil known' for R1, but a more specific value set to be considered for R3.
FHIR International Patient Summary - ValueSet: Absent or Unknown Allergies: https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/fhir-ips/ValueSet-absent-or-unknown-allergies-uv-ips.html#root

element.label: AdverseReactionRiskAbsenceItemR1
element.short: Adverse reaction risk absence item R1
element.definition: A positive statement of absence of information about known adverse reaction risks, accurate only at the time of recording.

extension.valueString:
Use to assert a clear and unambiguous statement about the absence of information about known adverse reaction risks in the health record. This approach is used in preference to the use of null flavours or terminology alone to represent missing data. It is intended for use within an Adverse reaction list or a health record extract.

element.label: FamilyHistoryR1
element.definition: No description

element.label: FamilyHistorySummaryItemR1
element.definition: A summary of significant health and related issues in family members.

extension.valueString:
Use to record a summary of information about problems or diagnoses found in family members. This information may be used to contribute to the identification of a current health problem, assessment of future risk from familial problems or conditions, or to initiate preventive health activities.

Traditionally the scope of family history has been focused on genetic factors or biomarkers as indicators of risk or potential risk. The scope of this item includes both recording of problems or diagnoses that have an inheritable origin as well as those that are not directly inheritable but influenced by the domestic setting, including psychosocial or environmental factors. Examples include exposure to toxins in the family environment, domestic violence, sexual abuse, alcoholism and other addictions.

Non-genetic family members can include adopted or long term fostered children, those related by marriage, or other unrelated individuals who participate in the regular life and influence of the family.

It may be necessary to identify each family member specifically and not just by the relationship to the individual. For example, while there will be only one maternal grandmother, there may be many female maternal cousins. This may be required to ensure that a pedigree chart is accurate. It will also enable accurate amendments to the record for each identified family member. If the record is private and will not be shared, for reasons of clarity it may be preferable to record the relative's actual name. If the record, or part of the record, is to be shared, it may be more appropriate for the family member to be identified by a unique label or alias.

Record as a single instance in a health record, updated and revised over time as a new version.

Family history, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-09-28]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.2469.

FamilyMemberHistory, FHIR Resource, R4 [Internet]. Health Level Seven International; [cited: 2020-09-28]. Available from: http://hl7.org/fhir/familymemberhistory.html.

element.label: ServiceRequestItem
element.definition: Health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency at a future time.

extension.valueString:
Use to record a request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.

This item has been designed as a framework that can be used as the basis for:
- a request from one clinician, organisation or agency to another clinician, organisation or agency for a health-related service. For example: a referral to a specialist clinician for treatment or a second clinical opinion; transfer of care to an emergency department; four hourly vital signs monitoring; and provision of home services from a municipal council; or
- a request for a follow up service to be scheduled for the same clinician, organisation or agency. For example: a review appointment in outpatients in 6 weeks.
Service request, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-09-28]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.614.

element.label: ServiceDue
element.definition: The date/time, interval of date/time or text representation when provision of the service should be completed.

extension.valueString:
Ideally this data element should allow for recording of the timing for a single service as a date and time, a date range, or a text descriptor which could allow for 'next available'. A choice of data types should allow for DateTime, Interval of DateTime, and text string.

In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as approximate timing, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months or in 3-4 weeks. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, the '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element.

element.label: Comment

element.comment:
PREFACE:
‘Gender identity’ and ‘Sex assigned at birth’ were included in DDR1 but have been further clarified in Phase 2 discussions with clinicians. In fact, Release 1’s ‘Birth sex’ has been updated and renamed to ‘Sex assigned at birth.
element.definition: Details about the gender of an individual.

extension.valueString:
Use to record a range of details about the individual's gender, including administrative and legal gender and assigned sex at birth, in addition to gender identity, expression and preferred pronoun.

Record as a single instance in a health record; updated and revised over time as a new version.

Not to be used for recording information relating to the sexual orientation or sexual activity of an individual.

Not to be used for recording genetic or chromosomal sex. Currently this is usually recorded as a laboratory test result. Formal representation of 'Genetic sex' is not yet well defined and may involve the combination of information axes, including chromosomal and receptor data, mosaic variants and diagnoses.

element.label: FamilyHistorySummaryItemR2
element.comment:
PREFACE:
The Family history summary item in Release 1 comprised only a single data element for a narrative description of significant clinical history of family members. The narrative description is useful to provide a narrative sense of the family history of an individual and can also be used to store narrative data about family history from existing clinical systems that are non-conformant with this structure or previously captured only as free text. 

<Insert Family history item R1.png here>
 
In Release 2, additional data elements have been added to allow information about familial health conditions to be recorded on a ‘Per family member’ basis. Clearly this kind of data needs to be recorded with privacy and confidentiality in mind, so each family member can be identified by an alias if necessary. This model is intended to describe data elements and their attributes that will support a useful digital family history record and potential development of a pedigree chart, where this might be useful in the health record.   

<Insert Family history item R2 AB.png here>
 
The addition of the ‘Per family member’ group (A) allows recording of a repeating group of data elements, one instance per family member. The ‘Clinical history’ group (B) allows recording of a repeating group of data elements, one instance per problem/diagnosis. This modelling pattern ensures that the Family history item can contain a simple narrative summary/overview about the family history, plus optional details about an unlimited number of family members and their health problems. 

The scope of the enhancement for Release 2 has been was based on a consensus decision by the Program’s Clinical Working Group. A candidate model for a comprehensive Family history record was presented to the CWG and a pragmatic subset was selected for inclusion in Release 2. The CWG decision criteria for inclusion focused on identifying data elements that would result in improved, consistent primary care records. The candidate model also demonstrated how detail in the Family history summary item might be further enhanced in future releases of the Data Dictionary, providing a strategy for compatible extensions in Release 3 or beyond.
element.definition: Summary or persistent information about significant health and related issues in family members.

extension.valueString:
Use to record a summary of information about problems or diagnoses found in family members. This information may be used to contribute to the identification of a current health problem, assessment of future risk from familial problems or conditions, or to initiate preventive health activities.

Traditionally the scope of family history has been focused on genetic factors or biomarkers as indicators of risk or potential risk. The scope of this item includes both recording of problems or diagnoses that have an inheritable origin as well as those that are not directly inheritable but influenced by the domestic setting, including psycho-social or environmental factors. Examples include exposure to toxins in the family environment, domestic violence, sexual abuse, alcoholism and other addictions.

Non-genetic family members can include adopted or long term fostered children, those related by marriage, or other unrelated individuals who participate in the regular life and influence of the family.

It may be necessary to identify each family member specifically and not just by the relationship to the individual. For example, while there will be only one maternal grandmother, there may be many female maternal cousins. This may be required to ensure that a pedigree chart is accurate. It will also enable accurate amendments to the record for each identified family member. If the record is private and will not be shared, for reasons of clarity it may be preferable to record the relative's actual name. If the record, or part of the record, is to be shared, it may be more appropriate for the family member to be identified by a unique label or alias.

Record as a single instance in a health record; updated and revised over time as a new version.

Family history, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-07-10]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.2469

FamilyMemberHistory, FHIR Resource, R4 [Internet]. Health Level Seven International; [cited: 2020-09-22]. Available from: http://hl7.org/fhir/familymemberhistory.html.

element.definition: Narrative summary about problems, diagnoses, psychosocial, environmental and genetic markers that have been identified in family members.

extension.valueString: This field can be used to record a summary or overview of the family history, for unstructured family history information recorded in clinical records, or to hold narrative only data from existing/legacy clinical systems.

element.label: TobaccoSmokingSummaryItemR2
element.comment:
PREFACE:
The specific scope of this item is on documentation about all types of inhaled tobacco smoke because of the associated health risks from direct inhalation of tobacco and associated chemicals. Other types of tobacco use, such as smokeless forms of tobacco should be modelled separately.

The 'Tobacco smoking summary item R1' comprised three optionable data elements – an overall status, an overall narrative description and a date last updated. The narrative description is useful to provide a narrative sense of the smoking habit and history for an individual and can also be used to store narrative data about tobacco smoking from existing clinical systems that are non-conformant with this structure or previously captured only as free text. The value set for tobacco smoking status is lifetime non-smoker, current smoker and former smoker.

<insert Tobacco smoking summary R1.png here>
   
In release 2, additional data elements have been added to allow some structured information about the tobacco smoking to be recorded which support health risk assessments related to tobacco smoking and development of quit smoking strategies for each individual. 
 
The pattern for recording tobacco smoking first identifies the type of tobacco smoked. It is possible for different types or forms of tobacco to be smoked, each with a different method of recording and potentially a different health risk. In future there may be a need to record episodes of smoking behaviour within each type of tobacco use, for example smoking while pregnant. This differs from the alcohol consumption pattern which is simpler because of the emphasis on the number of standard drinks rather than details about the type, strength and volume of alcohol.

Clinicians wanted to know when regular smoking of any type of tobacco commenced, as an indication of the length of smoking habit. It was also noted that in most Australian clinical systems it was incorrectly assumed that only cigarettes were smoked. This DDR2 model allows for any type of tobacco smoking to be recorded, including details about the use for each type. The ‘Per type’ heading is a repeating group of data elements related to each type of tobacco smoked - for example cigarettes (commercial or ‘roll your owns’), cigars, pipes, hookah etc, as required. The overall ‘Quit date’ for all types of tobacco has also been added, plus a calculation of ‘Overall pack years’ which can be calculated based on cigarettes, but also other types of tobacco.

<insert Tobacco smoking summary R2.png here>
  
The limitation of this model is that it implies that individuals don’t change how they smoke over time and that it is reasonable to record a ‘typical use’. Obviously actual use may vary enormously in reality. In future this model can be extended to capture varying patterns of tobacco smoking over time – for example, cutting down during a pregnancy but returning to previous levels after the birth. In addition, a complementary model could be added to support recording actual use, such as might be required for a smoking diary. 

The scope of the enhancement for Release 2 has been is based on a consensus decision by the Program’s Clinical Working Group. A candidate model for a comprehensive Tobacco smoking summary record was presented to the CWG and a pragmatic subset was selected for inclusion in Release 2. The CWG decision criteria for inclusion focussed on identifying data elements that would result in improved, consistent primary care records. The candidate model demonstrated how the Tobacco smoking item might be further enhanced in the future releases of the Data Dictionary, enabling a strategy for potential backwardly compatible extensions in Release 3 or beyond.
element.definition: Summary or persistent information about the typical tobacco smoking habits of the individual.

extension.valueString:
The 'Per type' cluster of data elements allows for recording of specific details and episodes about each type of tobacco smoked and can be repeated once per type.

In many situations the individual will only smoke one type of tobacco, such as manufactured cigarettes. If other types of tobacco are smoked, the details will be recorded in another instance of the 'Per type' cluster.

Use to incorporate the narrative descriptions of tobacco smoking habits within existing or legacy clinical systems into an archetyped format, using the 'Overall description' data element.

Record as a single instance in a health record; updated and revised over time as a new version.

Not to be used to record event- or period-based information about tobacco smoking, such as actual daily use or the average use over a specified period of time.
Not to be used to record nicotine and tar exposure.
Not to be used to record environmental exposure to cigarette smoke, for example passive smoking.

Pipe smoking

element.label: AlcoholConsumptionSummaryItermR2
element.comment:
PREFACE: 
The Alcohol consumption item in Release 1 comprised three optionable data elements – an overall status, an overall narrative description and a date last updated. The narrative description is useful to provide a narrative sense of the alcohol consumption habit and history for an individual and can also be used to store narrative data about alcohol consumption from existing clinical systems that are non-conformant with this structure or previously captured only as free text. The value set for alcohol consumption status is lifetime non-drinker, current drinker and former drinker.  

<Insert Alcohol consumption summary R1.png here>

In Release 2, additional data elements have been added to allow some structured information about the alcohol consumption to be recorded which support health risk assessments related to alcohol consumption and development of alcohol reduction strategies for each individual.  

The pattern for recording alcohol consumptions first identifies episodes. It may be that only one typical episode is ever recorded, although it is possible to represent episodes of sobriety or reduced drinking during pregnancy etc. The emphasis in this model is on the number of standard drinks rather than details about the type, strength and volume of alcohol.

<Insert Alcohol consumption summary R2.png here>
 
The scope of the enhancement for DDR2 has been is based on a consensus decision by the Program’s Clinical Working Group. A candidate model for a comprehensive Alcohol consumption summary was presented to the CWG and a pragmatic subset was selected for inclusion in Release 2. The CWG decision criteria for inclusion focussed on identifying data elements that would result in improved, consistent primary care records. The candidate model demonstrated how the alcohol consumption item might be further enhanced in the future releases of the Data Dictionary, enabling a strategy for potential backwardly compatible extensions in Release 3 or beyond.

element.label: SubstanceUseSummaryItem
element.comment:
PREFACE:
Given that tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption is ubiquitous and have well understood modelling requirements, these concepts have been modelled separately. Thus the scope of a substance in the context of this model is includes the administration or consumption of any psychoactive or biologically active substance (with the exception of tobacco and alcohol) used without a prescription or beyond its medical scope, intended purpose or dosage than prescribed.
element.definition: Summary or persistent information about the typical use of a non-prescribed substance or misuse of a prescribed substance by an individual.

extension.valueString:
Use to record summary information about the individual's typical pattern of substance use.

The scope of a substance in the context of this model is includes the administration or consumption of any psychoactive or biologically active substance (with the exception of tobacco and alcohol) used without a prescription or beyond its medical scope, intended purpose or dosage other than prescribed. The scope of this model does not differentiate between legal and illegal substances.

Record a single instance per substance, or class of substance, in a health record; updated over time as a new version.

Not to be used to represent tobacco smoking or alcohol consumption - use specific Tobacco smoking and Alcohol consumption models for this purpose.

Not to be used to record event- or period-based information about substance use, such as actual daily use or the average use over a specified period of time, as required for a diary or questionnaire.

Not to be used to record prescribed substances such as medical marijuana. This should be recorded using Medication-related models.

PREFACE:
Most systems allow various aspects of social history to be captured but the data is extremely
variable, inconsistent, and almost universally an unstructured narrative. In Release 2 the Data Dictionary contains data elements that support a pragmatic start point for recording structured data that will support provision of clinical care, drive clinical decision support or identify risks related to social determinants of health.
Contains:
- Social summary item (R1)
- Housing summary item
--- Housing record item
- Occupation summary item
- Education summary item

element.label: HousingSummaryItem
element.comment:
PREFACE: This clinical model is the first iteration of a more detailed record about housing. The ‘Housing summary item’ will provide a overview of all housing related information, comprising a narrative description only in Release 2. 

In the future, this model can be extended with more detailed data elements, including ‘Residential setting’ (including public place/temporary shelter) and ‘Housing security’ to support clinical data collections related to SDOH.

element.label: OccupationEpisodeItem
element.definition: Details about a single job or role carried out by an individual during a specified period of time.

extension.valueString:
Use to record details about a single occupation episode.

Designed to be nested within a clinically appropriate, standalone item which requires a consistent model for recording details about a single occupation episode - for example, to record details about each unique occupation episode within the context of the 'Occupation summary item' by inserting within the [Occupation episode] data element.

The scope of this item is inclusive of all occupations or activities undertaken by an individual. For example: a paid job or employment; unpaid work of any type such as a volunteer position; or roles such as being retired or a student.

Multiple instances of this item captured over time will result in the aggregation of a history of past and present jobs and/or roles.

An active, or current occupation may be implied from a 'Date commenced' but no 'Date ceased'.

An individual may carry out many simultaneous occupations, each of which may be paid or unpaid. Each occupation should be recorded in a separate instance of this item.

If occupation attributes change significantly, such as a change of role/title or number of hours, then this should be recorded as a separate instance of this item.

There may be some apparent or real overlap between the data elements in this item and occupation/employment details that may be stored as demographic details in clinical or administrative systems. The data elements in this item have been designed specifically to support clinical purposes including generation of a medical certificate to a current employer.

Record as a single instance per occupation episode in a health record; updated and revised over time as a new version.

Not to be used standalone, but nested within a standalone item such as the Occupation summary item.

Not to be used to record temporary changes or episodes within a single occupation record, such as being on leave or seconded. This is out of scope for this item and should be part of an employer's human relations system.

Not to be used for detailed descriptions of health risks or exposure to hazardous substances in the workplace. Use other items for this purpose.
Occupation record, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-09-21]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.2380

element.label: MedicationExclusionItemR3
element.definition: A positive statement about no known use of Medications, accurate only at the time of recording.

extension.valueString:
Use to assert a clear and unambiguous statement about the exclusion of known use of medications, either current or past, in the health record. This approach is used in preference to the use of flags or terminology alone to express negation. It is intended for use within a Medication List or a health record extract.

If the positive presence of a 'Medication item' has been added to the health record, this Exclusion item becomes redundant.

Record as a single instance in a health record; updated and revised over time as a new version each time it is asserted. 

An absence statement can only be considered correct and accurate at the time it was asserted.
Not to be used to record the absence of any available information about Medication - use the Medication absence item.
Exclusion - global, Published archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-08-24]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.2733

element.label: ExaminationEyeItemR3
element.short: Examination of an eye item R3
element.definition: Findings observed during the physical examination of a single eye.

extension.valueString:
Use to record details of the findings observed during the physical examination of a single eye.

Designed to be nested within a clinically appropriate, standalone item which requires a consistent model for recording details about a single medication - for example, to extend the Physical examination findings item by inserting within the [Examination detail] data element.

Free text descriptions of clinical findings from existing or legacy clinical systems may be recorded in this item using the 'Clinical description' data element.

Record as a single instance per consultation in a health record.

Not to be used standalone, but nested within a clinically appropriate standalone item such as the Physical examination findings item.

Not to be used to record findings about both eyes simultaneously.
Examination of an eye, Draft archetype [Internet]. openEHR Foundation, openEHR Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2020-09-28]. Available from: https://ckm.openehr.org/ckm/archetypes/1013.1.3786.
